results.title: Television receivers
results.creator_credit: Loucks and Norling Studios and McGraw-Hill Text-Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic Television”
Diagrams and live action are used to identify the sections of the receiver circuit and to summarise the functions of the receiver. Explains the specific functions of each section in a typical intercarrier sound receiver circuit, from the antenna and transmission line to the picture tube.

results.title: Localising troubles
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic Television”.
An intercarrier sound receiver using the flyback high voltage supply is used as a typical example in explaining how to identify trouble symptoms and localise them in a specific section of the receiver by studying the three indicators present in the receiver itself - raster, picture and sound.

results.title: The Use of operational research - Part 1 cutting the queue
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basis for Decision”.
Operational research calculates the probable results of alternate courses of action for planning purposes. Many problems of organisations have similar structures and can be solved by similar methods of analysis and similar mathematical models. One simple structure, the input-service- output situation, is discussed and applied to different queuing problems.

results.title: The Human factor
results.creator_credit: Robert McIntosh, Jill Wood and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Basis for Decision”.
Unlike the other films in the series, the Operational Research scientists here look at two studies in which the central problems were human ones. One study was to find how to reduce labour wastage at collieries, the other studied a hospital with high staff turnover and which kept patients longer. Also looks to future potential - in advertising and human relations in industry; in town planning and local government; in transport policy and economic planning in central government.

results.title: History & styles of rock music in Australia
results.creator_credit: Euan Mitchell, Sylvie Leber, John Foss, Australian Contemporary Music Development Co (AUSMUSIC) and Serious Business
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic music industry skills”.
Introduction to the Music Industry. Module 4.1. A fascinating look at the development of Australian rock music from its humble beginnings during Johnny O’Keefe’s “Wild One” days in the mid 1950’s, the struggles to gain recognition at home and overseas in the ‘60’s and ‘70’s to the international success of Australian acts in the ‘80’s and the diversity of styles in the ‘90’s. Through personal accounts, photographs and music video clips we examine, decade by decade, the music styles, fashions, changing technology and trends in Australian rock music including legendary performers such as The Easybeats, Russell Morris, AC/DC, Skyhooks, Cold Chisel and Midnight Oil.

results.title: Playing it through
results.creator_credit: Julian Cooper, Jill Wood and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Basis for Decision”.
Critical path scheduling is discussed with examples from shipbuilding. Two examples of simulation methods are shown, scheduling production in a steel works and examining military problems.

results.title: Making a music video on the cheap: from concept to completion
results.creator_credit: Greg Ferguson, AUSMUSIC and Conspiracy Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic music industry skills”.
Module 21.2. This program demonstrates how a broadcast quality music video can be made for around $1,000. Shows the operation of a video camera and techniques such as white balance. Australian band Pelican Jed, take the viewer through a step by step analysis of their latest music video, highlighting the roles played by each member of the production team including interviews with the producer and director. The emphasis is to take the viewer from the concept stage to completion; where an idea becomes a reality.

results.title: Songlines: contemporary aboriginal music (A)
results.creator_credit: Richard Frankland, John Foss, Australian Contemporary Music Development Co (AUSMUSIC) and Golden Seahorse Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic music industry skills”.
Introduction to the Music Industry. Module 4.6. Contemporary Australian Aboriginal music has become an international presence in recent years. This program profiles artists who have taken their brand of indigenous music to the world: Yothu Yindi, Archie Roach and Tiddas. Traditional elements are incorporated into contemporary styles. This is not simply a matter of throwing in the odd didjeridu and clap stick, but rather the traditional cultural role of Aboriginal music as an educational medium is maintained and extended to cover new, important issues and themes.

results.title: Basic music industry skills
results.brief_description: Basic Music Industry Skills is an accredited Certificate Level Course suitable for use across the Years 9 to 12 curriculum. It is divided into modules focusing on different aspects of the music industry. Geared specifically to a teenage audience, it is nevertheless both informative and entertaining.
